mn95:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena opāsādaṃ nāma kosalānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
mn95:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Opāsāda.
mn95:1.2.comm: Opāsāda does not appear anywhere else. We later hear of Caṅkī’s longhouse (pāsāda), a luxurious residence to the north of the town on the way to the Godswood. Perhaps, then, Opāsāda means “below the mansion”.

mn95:1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā opāsāde viharati uttarena opāsādaṃ devavane sālavane.
mn95:1.3.eng: He stayed in the Godswood of sal trees to the north of Opāsāda.
mn95:1.3.comm: A grove in which offerings were made to the gods.

mn95:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena caṅkī brāhmaṇo opāsādaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ.
mn95:2.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī was living in Opāsāda. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
mn95:2.1.comm: Caṅkī is regularly mentioned along with other senior brahmins Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jānussoṇi, and Todeyya (DN 13:2.2, MN 98:2.2, MN 99:13.5, Snp 3.9:1.4). His name is obscure; spelled caṅgī in Sanskrit, it is perhaps related to the gatāgate caṅgimā of Mahā-subhāṣita-Saṁgraha 7235-1, where it refers to the sensual walk of a young woman; dictionaries record the sense “beautiful” for Kannada caṁgi and Sanskrit caṅgiman. | “Royal park” is rājadāya (cp. migadāya, “deer park”). | A brahmadeyya is a gift of land by a king to a brahmin, which was an outstanding feature of Indian feudalism. Similar grants are mentioned in the Dīgha Nikāya at DN 3:1.2.1, DN 5:1.4, DN 12:1.3, and DN 23:1.4.

mn95:3.1.eng: The brahmins and householders of Opāsāda heard:

mn95:3.2.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ opāsādaṃ anuppatto, opāsāde viharati uttarena opāsādaṃ devavane sālavane.
mn95:3.2.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the Godswood to the north.

mn95:3.3.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn95:3.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn95:3.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn95:3.5.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn95:3.5.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn95:3.6.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn95:3.6.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

mn95:3.7.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
mn95:3.7.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

mn95:4.1.pli: Atha kho opāsādakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā opāsādā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena devavanaṃ sālavanaṃ.
mn95:4.1.eng: Then, exiting Opāsāda, they formed into companies and headed north to the Godswood.

mn95:5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena caṅkī brāhmaṇo uparipāsāde divāseyyaṃ upagato.
mn95:5.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.
mn95:5.1.comm: Also a favored siesta location for Soṇadaṇḍa (DN 5:3.1), Kūṭadanta (DN 4:3.1), and Pāyāsi (DN 23:3.1).

mn95:5.2.pli: Addasā kho caṅkī brāhmaṇo opāsādake brāhmaṇagahapatike opāsādā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūte uttarenamukhaṃ yena devavanaṃ sālavanaṃ tenupasaṅkamante.
mn95:5.2.eng: He saw the brahmins and householders heading for the Godswood,

mn95:5.3.comm: The khatta (“butler”; Sanskrit kṣattṛ) was a senior member of the household staff, responsible for management of activities (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.3.1.7).

mn95:5.4.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bho khatte, opāsādakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā opāsādā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena devavanaṃ sālavanan”ti?
mn95:5.4.eng: “My butler, why are the brahmins and householders heading north for the Godswood?”

mn95:6.1.pli: “Atthi, bho caṅkī, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ opāsādaṃ anuppatto, opāsāde viharati uttarena opāsādaṃ devavane sālavane.
mn95:6.1.eng: “The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the Godswood to the north.

mn95:6.2.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn95:6.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn95:6.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn95:6.4.eng: They’re going to see that worthy Gotama.”

mn95:6.5.pli: “Tena hi, bho khatte, yena opāsādakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā opāsādake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṃ vadehi:
mn95:6.5.eng: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders and say to them:

mn95:6.7.pli: āgamentu kira bhonto, caṅkīpi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’”ti.
mn95:6.7.eng: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Gotama.’”

mn95:6.8.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho so khatto caṅkissa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena opāsādakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā opāsādake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca:
mn95:6.8.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the butler, and did as he was asked.

mn95:6.10.pli: ‘āgamentu kira bhonto, caṅkīpi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’”ti.

mn95:7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nānāverajjakānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pañcamattāni brāhmaṇasatāni opāsāde paṭivasanti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mn95:7.1.eng: Now at that time around five hundred brahmins from abroad were residing in Opāsāda on some business.

mn95:7.3.pli: “caṅkī kira brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.
mn95:7.3.eng: the brahmin Caṅkī was going to see the ascetic Gotama.

mn95:7.4.pli: Atha kho te brāhmaṇā yena caṅkī brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā caṅkiṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn95:7.4.eng: They approached Caṅkī and said to him,

mn95:7.5.pli: “saccaṃ kira bhavaṃ caṅkī samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti?
mn95:7.5.eng: “Is it really true that you are going to see the ascetic Gotama?”

mn95:8.1.pli: “Mā bhavaṃ caṅkī samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkami.

mn95:8.2.pli: Na arahati bhavaṃ caṅkī samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:8.2.eng: It’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;

mn95:8.3.pli: samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ caṅkiṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
mn95:8.3.eng: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.

mn95:8.4.pli: Bhavañhi caṅkī ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.
mn95:8.4.eng: You are well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.
mn95:8.4.comm: Jātivāda is sometimes translated as “doctrine of birth”, but the context here shows this cannot be the case. It refers to the genealogical records of the family lineage.

mn95:8.5.pli: Yampi bhavaṃ caṅkī ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ caṅkī samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:8.5.eng: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;

mn95:8.6.pli: samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ caṅkiṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
mn95:8.6.eng: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.

mn95:8.8.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ, padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo …pe…
mn95:8.8.eng: You recite and remember the hymns, and have mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. You know them word-by-word, and their grammar. You are well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. …

mn95:8.9.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya …pe…
mn95:8.9.eng: You are attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. You have divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …
mn95:8.9.comm: Brahmavarcasa (“divine lustre”) commonly describes a spiritual or ethereal beauty due to ritual (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.1.9, 2.3.1, 4.1.1), or simply the healthy glow from time in the sun, which if overdone leads to sunburn (eg. Taittirīya Saṁhita 2.10.2). Brahmavarṇa (“divine looks”), on the other hand, seems unknown in the Vedic tradition. | For Mahāsaṅgīti vacchasī read vaccasī (Sanskrit varcasin), “possessing lustre”.

mn95:8.10.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato …pe…
mn95:8.10.eng: You are ethical, mature in ethical conduct. …

mn95:8.11.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā …pe…
mn95:8.11.eng: You’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …

mn95:8.12.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo, tīṇi māṇavakasatāni mante vāceti …pe…
mn95:8.12.eng: You teach the tutors of many, and teach three hundred young students to recite the hymns. …
mn95:8.12.comm: Notice that the royal endowment was not just for a luxury residence, it was the site of a major international college. Kings invested in education.

mn95:8.13.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī rañño pasenadissa kosalassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
mn95:8.13.eng: You’re honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Pasenadi of Kosala

mn95:8.14.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…

mn95:8.15.pli: bhavañhi caṅkī opāsādaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ.
mn95:8.15.eng: You live in Opāsāda, a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.

mn95:8.16.pli: Yampi bhavaṃ caṅkī opāsādaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ caṅkī samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:8.16.eng: For all these reasons it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;

mn95:8.17.pli: samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ caṅkiṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitun”ti.
mn95:8.17.eng: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.”

mn95:9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, caṅkī brāhmaṇo te brāhmaṇe etadavoca:
mn95:9.1.eng: When they had spoken, Caṅkī said to those brahmins:

mn95:9.2.pli: “tena hi, bho, mamapi suṇātha, yathā mayameva arahāma taṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:9.2.eng: “Well then, gentlemen, listen to why it’s appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama,

mn95:9.3.pli: na tveva arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
mn95:9.3.eng: and it’s not appropriate for him to come to see me.

mn95:9.4.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena.
mn95:9.4.eng: He is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.

mn95:9.5.pli: Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:9.5.eng: For this reason it’s not appropriate for the ascetic Gotama to come to see me;

mn95:9.6.pli: atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
mn95:9.6.eng: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.

mn95:9.7.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajito bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhañca …pe…
mn95:9.7.eng: When he went forth he abandoned abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. …

mn95:9.8.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo daharova samāno yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito …pe…
mn95:9.8.eng: He went forth from the lay life to homelessness while still a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life. …

mn95:9.9.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ assumukhānaṃ rudantānaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito …pe…
mn95:9.9.eng: Though his mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces, he shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness. …

mn95:9.10.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya …pe…
mn95:9.10.eng: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He has divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …

mn95:9.11.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sīlavā ariyasīlī kusalasīlī kusalena sīlena samannāgato …pe…
mn95:9.11.eng: He is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is noble and skillful. …

mn95:9.12.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā …pe…
mn95:9.12.eng: He’s a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …

mn95:9.13.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo …pe…

mn95:9.14.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khīṇakāmarāgo vigatacāpallo …pe…
mn95:9.14.eng: He has ended sensual desire, and is rid of caprice. …

mn95:9.15.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kammavādī kiriyavādī apāpapurekkhāro brahmaññāya pajāya …pe…
mn95:9.15.eng: He teaches the efficacy of deeds and action. He doesn’t wish any harm upon the community of brahmins. …

mn95:9.16.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo uccā kulā pabbajito asambhinnā khattiyakulā …pe…
mn95:9.16.eng: He went forth from an eminent family of unbroken aristocratic lineage. …

mn95:9.17.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo aḍḍhā kulā pabbajito mahaddhanā mahābhogā …pe…
mn95:9.17.eng: He went forth from a rich, affluent, and wealthy family. …

mn95:9.18.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ tiroraṭṭhā tirojanapadā saṃpucchituṃ āgacchanti …pe…
mn95:9.18.eng: People come from distant lands and distant countries to question him. …
mn95:9.18.comm: “Distant land” (tiroraṭṭha) is defined at Bi Pc 38:2.6 as “any land other than where one is living”.

mn95:9.19.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ anekāni devatāsahassāni pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gatāni …pe…
mn95:9.19.eng: Many thousands of deities have gone for refuge for life to him. …

mn95:9.20.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn95:9.21.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti …pe…
mn95:9.21.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ …

mn95:9.22.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato …pe…
mn95:9.22.eng: He has the thirty-two marks of a great man. …

mn95:9.23.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saputtadāro pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato …pe…
mn95:9.23.eng: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …

mn95:9.24.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo saputtadāro pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato …pe…
mn95:9.24.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …

mn95:9.25.pli: Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti saputtadāro pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato …pe…
mn95:9.25.eng: The brahmin Pokkharasāti and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
mn95:9.25.comm: Refuge of Pokkharasāti and family is at DN 3:2.22.4.

mn95:9.26.pli: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo opāsādaṃ anuppatto opāsāde viharati uttarena opāsādaṃ devavane sālavane.
mn95:9.26.eng: The ascetic Gotama has arrived to stay in the Godswood to the north of Opāsāda.

mn95:9.27.pli: Ye kho te samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amhākaṃ gāmakkhettaṃ āgacchanti, atithī no te honti.
mn95:9.27.eng: Any ascetic or brahmin who comes to stay in our village district is our guest,

mn95:9.28.pli: Atithī kho panamhehi sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā.
mn95:9.28.eng: and should be honored and respected as such.

mn95:9.29.pli: Yampi samaṇo gotamo opāsādaṃ anuppatto opāsāde viharati uttarena opāsādaṃ devavane sālavane, atithimhākaṃ samaṇo gotamo.

mn95:9.30.pli: Atithi kho panamhehi sakkātabbo garukātabbo mānetabbo pūjetabbo.

mn95:9.31.pli: Imināpaṅgena na arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:9.31.eng: For this reason, too, it’s not appropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,

mn95:9.32.pli: atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
mn95:9.32.eng: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.

mn95:9.33.pli: Ettake kho ahaṃ, bho, tassa bhoto gotamassa vaṇṇe pariyāpuṇāmi, no ca kho so bhavaṃ gotamo ettakavaṇṇo;
mn95:9.33.eng: This is the extent of the worthy Gotama’s praise that I have memorized. But his praises are not confined to this,

mn95:9.34.eng: for the praise of the worthy Gotama is limitless.

mn95:9.35.pli: Ekamekenapi tena aṅgena samannāgato na arahati, so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ;
mn95:9.35.eng: The possession of even a single one of these factors makes it inappropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,

mn95:9.36.pli: atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitunti.
mn95:9.36.eng: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.

mn95:9.37.pli: Tena hi, bho, sabbeva mayaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā”ti.
mn95:9.37.eng: Well then, gentlemen, let’s all go to see the ascetic Gotama.”

mn95:10.1.pli: Atha kho caṅkī brāhmaṇo mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn95:10.1.eng: Then Caṅkī together with a large group of brahmins went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

mn95:10.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn95:10.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

mn95:11.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā vuddhehi vuddhehi brāhmaṇehi saddhiṃ kiñci kiñci kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā nisinno hoti.
mn95:11.1.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting engaged in some polite conversation together with some very senior brahmins.

mn95:11.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kāpaṭiko nāma māṇavo daharo vuttasiro soḷasavassuddesiko jātiyā, tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ, padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti.
mn95:11.2.eng: And the student Kāpaṭika was sitting in that assembly. He was young, tonsured, and sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
mn95:11.2.comm: This student’s education is like that of Assalāyana (MN 93:3.1), but his character could not be more different. His name has a variety of spellings in Pali and Sanskrit, but the correct form is kāpaṭika from kapaṭa, “fraud”. Kauṭilya explains that fraudulent students (chātraḥ kāpaṭikaḥ) were spies installed by kings to test the loyalty of subjects (Arthaśāstra 1.10.11, 1.11.1–2), for which they were paid handsomely (5.3.22). Note that the Buddha calls him Bhāradvāja; this follows the convention in Pali that brahmins of that name are distinguished by epithets, often unflattering: Bhāradvāja the Farmer (Snp 1.4:1.3), Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper (Snp 1.7:1.4), Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer (SN 35.127:1.1), Bhāradvāja the Builder (SN 7.17:1.2), Bhāradvāja the Rude (SN 7.2:1.2), Bhāradvāja the Fiend (SN 7.3:1.2), Bhāradvāja the Bitter (SN 7.4:1.2), and so on. Thus Kāpaṭika would have been an epithet recognizing that he was the king’s spy, a practice to which Pasenadi openly admits (SN 3.11:7.1, Ud 6.2:8.1). This was the downside of building a religious institution on the king’s largess. Whether he was recognized as a spy at the time, or the epithet was applied later, is uncertain, but at some point it seems the meaning was forgotten and the epithet was taken to be his proper name.

mn95:11.3.pli: So vuddhānaṃ vuddhānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ bhagavatā saddhiṃ mantayamānānaṃ antarantarā kathaṃ opāteti.
mn95:11.3.eng: While the senior brahmins were conversing together with the Buddha, he interrupted.

mn95:11.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kāpaṭikaṃ māṇavaṃ apasādeti:

mn95:11.5.pli: “māyasmā bhāradvājo vuddhānaṃ vuddhānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ mantayamānānaṃ antarantarā kathaṃ opātetu.
mn95:11.5.eng: “Venerable Bhāradvāja, don’t interrupt the senior brahmins.
mn95:11.5.comm: It is rare for the Buddha to address a lay person as “venerable” (āyasmā). It seems the form is excessively polite to soften the rebuke.

mn95:11.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, caṅkī brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn95:11.7.eng: When he had spoken, Caṅkī said to the Buddha,

mn95:11.8.eng: “Worthy Gotama, don’t rebuke the student Kāpaṭika.

mn95:11.9.pli: kulaputto ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, bahussuto ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, paṇḍito ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, kalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, pahoti ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo bhotā gotamena saddhiṃ asmiṃ vacane paṭimantetun”ti.
mn95:11.9.eng: He’s a gentleman, learned and astute, who enunciates well. He is capable of debating with the worthy Gotama about this.”

mn95:12.1.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
mn95:12.1.comm: This passage is unique to to this sutta.

mn95:12.2.pli: “addhā kho kāpaṭikassa māṇavassa tevijjake pāvacane kathā bhavissati.
mn95:12.2.eng: “Clearly the student Kāpaṭika will talk about the scriptural heritage of the three Vedas.

mn95:12.3.eng: That’s why the brahmins put him at the front.”

mn95:12.5.pli: “yadā me samaṇo gotamo cakkhuṃ upasaṃharissati, athāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pañhaṃ pucchissāmī”ti.
mn95:12.5.eng: “When the ascetic Gotama looks at me, I’ll ask him a question.”

mn95:12.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kāpaṭikassa māṇavassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena kāpaṭiko māṇavo tena cakkhūni upasaṃhāsi.
mn95:12.6.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing Kāpaṭika’s train of thought, looked at him.

mn95:12.8.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is engaging with me.

mn95:12.9.eng: Why don’t I ask him a question?”

mn95:12.10.pli: Atha kho kāpaṭiko māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

mn95:12.11.pli: “yadidaṃ, bho gotama, brāhmaṇānaṃ porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ itihitihaparamparāya piṭakasampadāya, tattha ca brāhmaṇā ekaṃsena niṭṭhaṃ gacchanti:
mn95:12.11.eng: “Worthy Gotama, regarding that which by the lineage of testament and by canonical authority is the ancient hymnal of the brahmins, the brahmins come to the categorical conclusion:
mn95:12.11.comm: The “lineage of testament” (itihitihaparamparā); “canonical authority” (piṭakasampadā); “ancient hymnal” (porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ): these refer to the Vedas.

mn95:12.12.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn95:12.13.eng: What do you say about this?”

mn95:13.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhāradvāja, atthi koci brāhmaṇānaṃ ekabrāhmaṇopi yo evamāha:
mn95:13.1.eng: “Well, Bhāradvāja, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:

mn95:13.3.eng: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

mn95:13.5.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhāradvāja, atthi koci brāhmaṇānaṃ ekācariyopi, ekācariyapācariyopi, yāva sattamā ācariyamahayugāpi, yo evamāha:
mn95:13.5.eng: “Well, is there even a single tutor of the brahmins, or a tutors’ tutor, or anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors, who says this:

mn95:13.7.eng: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

mn95:13.9.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhāradvāja, yepi te brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro yesamidaṃ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti seyyathidaṃ—aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu,
mn95:13.9.eng: “Well, what of the ancient seers of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
mn95:13.9.comm: The ten names in Pali include the seven authors of the so-called “family books” of the Rig Veda (Maṇḍalas 2–8). As founders of poetic lineages, we often find works by their descendants, which are not always confined to their dedicated family book. Poems by the other three authors are mostly outside the family books. Thus the sages listed here cover most of the Rig Veda, although the Vedic tradition records many other authors as well. | Atri Bhauma (Maṇḍala 5, rather than Aṣṭaka Vaiśvāmitra of 10.104); Vamra(ka) Vaikhānasa (10.99; see 9.66); Vāmadeva Gautama (Maṇḍala 4); Viśvāmitra Gāthina (Maṇḍala 3); Jamadagni Bhārgava was a descendant of Bhṛgu (several hymns mostly in Maṇḍalas 9 and 10); Aṅgirasa is identified with Agni as the founder of a lineage of poet-singers (Maṇḍala 8); Bharadvāja Bārhaspatya (Maṇḍala 6); Vasiṣṭha Maitrāvaruṇi (Maṇḍala 7); Kaśyapa Mārīca (several hymns mostly in Maṇḍalas 9 and 10); Bhṛgu was the bringer of fire from heaven whose adoptive descendant was Gṛtsamada Bhārgava Śaunaka (Maṇḍala 2).

mn95:13.12.eng: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

mn95:13.14.pli: “Iti kira, bhāradvāja, natthi koci brāhmaṇānaṃ ekabrāhmaṇopi yo evamāha:
mn95:13.14.eng: “So, Bhāradvāja, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,

mn95:13.17.pli: natthi koci brāhmaṇānaṃ ekācariyopi ekācariyapācariyopi, yāva sattamā ācariyamahayugāpi, yo evamāha:
mn95:13.17.eng: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors,

mn95:13.20.pli: yepi te brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro yesamidaṃ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti seyyathidaṃ—aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamāhaṃsu:
mn95:13.20.eng: nor even the ancient seers of the brahmins who say:

mn95:13.22.eng: this is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn95:13.23.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, andhaveṇi paramparāsaṃsattā purimopi na passati majjhimopi na passati pacchimopi na passati;
mn95:13.23.eng: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
mn95:13.23.comm: The “blind following the blind” is also at MN 95:13.24 and MN 99:9.25. Maitrī Upaniṣad 7.8–9 turns it around, saying that the blind teach false doctrines aimed at destroying the Vedas, “the doctrine of not-self” (nairātmyavāda), an obvious reference to Buddhists. We also find it at Kaṭha Upaniṣad 1.2.5, Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 1.2.8, Mahābhārata 2.38.3, and the Jain Sūyagaḍa 1.1.2.19.

mn95:13.24.pli: evameva kho, bhāradvāja, andhaveṇūpamaṃ maññe brāhmaṇānaṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjati—purimopi na passati majjhimopi na passati pacchimopi na passati.
mn95:13.24.eng: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be like a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.

mn95:13.26.pli: nanu evaṃ sante brāhmaṇānaṃ amūlikā saddhā sampajjatī”ti?
mn95:13.26.eng: This being so, doesn’t the brahmins’ faith turn out to be baseless?”

mn95:14.1.pli: “Na khvettha, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā saddhāyeva payirupāsanti, anussavāpettha brāhmaṇā payirupāsantī”ti.
mn95:14.1.eng: “The brahmins don’t just honor this because of faith, but also because of oral transmission.”
mn95:14.1.comm: “Faith” is saddhā (see note on MN 26:15.9) | “Oral transmission” is anussava. While the idea of oral tradition was of course central to Vedism, we don’t seem to find the term until later (eg. Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.8.29; Śrīdhara’s commentary on Bhagavad-Gītā 18.3). | See too MN 76:24.1.

mn95:14.2.pli: “Pubbeva kho tvaṃ, bhāradvāja, saddhaṃ agamāsi, anussavaṃ idāni vadesi.
mn95:14.2.eng: “First you relied on faith, now you speak of oral transmission.

mn95:14.3.pli: Pañca kho ime, bhāradvāja, dhammā diṭṭheva dhamme dvedhā vipākā.
mn95:14.3.eng: These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways.

mn95:14.5.eng: Faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, and acceptance of a view after deliberation.
mn95:14.5.comm: Parivitakka means “train of thought”, as when the Buddha reads Kāpaṭika’s thoughts above (MN 95:12.6). Ākāra in this context means “reason”, as at MN 47:10.2; the current sutta expands on the ideas there. | Khanti is usually better rendered “acceptance” than the common “patience”.

mn95:14.6.pli: ime kho, bhāradvāja, pañca dhammā diṭṭheva dhamme dvedhā vipākā.

mn95:14.7.pli: Api ca, bhāradvāja, susaddahitaṃyeva hoti, tañca hoti rittaṃ tucchaṃ musā;
mn95:14.7.eng: Even though you have full faith in something, it may be vacuous, hollow, and false.

mn95:14.8.pli: no cepi susaddahitaṃ hoti, tañca hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anaññathā.
mn95:14.8.eng: And even if you don’t have full faith in something, it may be true and real, not otherwise.

mn95:14.9.eng: Even though you fully endorse something …
mn95:14.9.comm: Ruci means “liking, preference”, and from there takes the sense of “endorsing” an idea or belief, in which case it can be translated as “opinion”.

mn95:14.11.eng: something may be well thought out …

mn95:14.12.pli: sunijjhāyitaṃyeva hoti, tañca hoti rittaṃ tucchaṃ musā;
mn95:14.12.eng: something may be well deliberated, it may be vacuous, hollow, and false.

mn95:14.13.pli: no cepi sunijjhāyitaṃ hoti, tañca hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anaññathā.
mn95:14.13.eng: And even if something is not well deliberated, it may be true and real, not otherwise.

mn95:14.14.pli: Saccamanurakkhatā, bhāradvāja, viññunā purisena nālamettha ekaṃsena niṭṭhaṃ gantuṃ:
mn95:14.14.eng: For a sensible person who is preserving truth this is not sufficient to come to the categorical conclusion:
mn95:14.14.comm: This sutta introduces the important epistemological distinction between the “preservation of truth” (saccānurakkhaṇā), the “awakening to the truth” (saccānubodha), and the “attainment of the truth” (saccānuppatti).

mn95:14.15.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’”

mn95:15.1.pli: “Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, kittāvatā saccamanurakkhati?
mn95:15.1.eng: “But worthy Gotama, how do you define the preservation of truth?”

mn95:15.4.eng: they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is my faith.’

mn95:15.5.pli: iti vadaṃ saccamanurakkhati, na tveva tāva ekaṃsena niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn95:15.5.eng: But they don’t yet come to the categorical conclusion:

mn95:15.6.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn95:15.7.eng: If a person has a belief …

mn95:15.8.eng: or has received an oral transmission …

mn95:15.9.eng: or has a reasoned reflection about something …

mn95:15.10.eng: or has accepted a view after contemplation,

mn95:15.11.eng: they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is the view I have accepted after contemplation.’

mn95:15.12.pli: iti vadaṃ saccamanurakkhati, na tveva tāva ekaṃsena niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn95:15.12.eng: But they don’t yet come to the categorical conclusion:

mn95:15.13.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn95:15.14.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhāradvāja, saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, ettāvatā saccamanurakkhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānurakkhaṇaṃ paññapema;
mn95:15.14.eng: That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the preservation of truth as defined in this way.
mn95:15.14.comm: This is essentially the standard used in references today: one should accurately represent one’s sources.

mn95:15.15.eng: But this is not yet the awakening to the truth.”

mn95:16.1.pli: “Ettāvatā, bho gotama, saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, ettāvatā saccamanurakkhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānurakkhaṇaṃ pekkhāma.
mn95:16.1.eng: “That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, worthy Gotama. We regard the preservation of truth as defined in this way.

mn95:16.2.pli: Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, saccānubodho hoti, kittāvatā saccamanubujjhati?
mn95:16.2.eng: But worthy Gotama, how do you define awakening to the truth?”

mn95:17.1.pli: “Idha, bhāradvāja, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
mn95:17.1.eng: “Bhāradvāja, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.

mn95:17.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā tīsu dhammesu samannesati—
mn95:17.2.eng: A householder or their child approaches and scrutinizes them for three kinds of things:

mn95:17.3.pli: lobhanīyesu dhammesu, dosanīyesu dhammesu, mohanīyesu dhammesu.
mn95:17.3.eng: things that arouse greed, things that provoke hate, and things that promote delusion.
mn95:17.3.comm: For these phrases, compare AN 4.117 and AN 5.144.

mn95:17.4.pli: Atthi nu kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā lobhanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi lobhanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṃ vā vadeyya—
mn95:17.4.eng: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that arouse greed? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say

mn95:17.5.eng: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;

mn95:17.6.pli: passāmīti, paraṃ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṃ paresaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti?
mn95:17.6.eng: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’

mn95:17.8.pli: ‘natthi kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā lobhanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi lobhanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṃ vā vadeyya—
mn95:17.8.eng: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that arouse greed.

mn95:17.10.pli: passāmīti, paraṃ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṃ paresaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.

mn95:17.11.pli: Tathārūpo kho panimassāyasmato kāyasamācāro tathārūpo vacīsamācāro yathā taṃ aluddhassa.
mn95:17.11.eng: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without greed.

mn95:17.12.pli: Yaṃ kho pana ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ deseti, gambhīro so dhammo duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo;
mn95:17.12.eng: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.

mn95:17.13.eng: It’s not easy for someone with greed to teach this.’

mn95:18.1.pli: Yato naṃ samannesamāno visuddhaṃ lobhanīyehi dhammehi samanupassati tato naṃ uttari samannesati dosanīyesu dhammesu.
mn95:18.1.eng: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that arouse greed. Next, they search them for qualities that provoke hate.

mn95:18.2.pli: Atthi nu kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā dosanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi dosanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṃ vā vadeyya—
mn95:18.2.eng: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that provoke hate? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say

mn95:18.3.eng: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;

mn95:18.4.pli: passāmīti, paraṃ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṃ paresaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti?
mn95:18.4.eng: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’

mn95:18.6.pli: ‘natthi kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā dosanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi dosanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṃ vā vadeyya—
mn95:18.6.eng: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that provoke hate.

mn95:18.8.pli: passāmīti, paraṃ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṃ paresaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.

mn95:18.9.pli: Tathārūpo kho panimassāyasmato kāyasamācāro tathārūpo vacīsamācāro yathā taṃ aduṭṭhassa.
mn95:18.9.eng: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without hate.

mn95:18.10.pli: Yaṃ kho pana ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ deseti, gambhīro so dhammo duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo;
mn95:18.10.eng: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.

mn95:18.11.eng: It’s not easy for someone with hate to teach this.’

mn95:19.1.pli: Yato naṃ samannesamāno visuddhaṃ dosanīyehi dhammehi samanupassati, tato naṃ uttari samannesati mohanīyesu dhammesu.
mn95:19.1.eng: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that provoke hate. Next, they scrutinize them for qualities that promote delusion.

mn95:19.2.pli: Atthi nu kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā mohanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi mohanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṃ vā vadeyya—
mn95:19.2.eng: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that promote delusion? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say

mn95:19.3.eng: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;

mn95:19.4.pli: passāmīti, paraṃ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṃ paresaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti?
mn95:19.4.eng: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’

mn95:19.6.pli: ‘natthi kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā mohanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi mohanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṃ vā vadeyya—
mn95:19.6.eng: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that promote delusion.

mn95:19.8.pli: passāmīti, paraṃ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṃ paresaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.

mn95:19.9.pli: Tathārūpo kho panimassāyasmato kāyasamācāro tathārūpo vacīsamācāro yathā taṃ amūḷhassa.
mn95:19.9.eng: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without delusion.

mn95:19.10.pli: Yaṃ kho pana ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ deseti, gambhīro so dhammo duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo;
mn95:19.10.eng: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.

mn95:19.11.eng: It’s not easy for someone with delusion to teach this.’

mn95:20.1.pli: Yato naṃ samannesamāno visuddhaṃ mohanīyehi dhammehi samanupassati;
mn95:20.1.eng: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that promote delusion.

mn95:20.2.pli: atha tamhi saddhaṃ niveseti, saddhājāto upasaṅkamati, upasaṅkamanto payirupāsati, payirupāsanto sotaṃ odahati, ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti, sutvā dhammaṃ dhāreti, dhatānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati, atthaṃ upaparikkhato dhammā nijjhānaṃ khamanti, dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā sati chando jāyati, chandajāto ussahati, ussahitvā tuleti, tulayitvā padahati, pahitatto samāno kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti paññāya ca naṃ ativijjha passati.
mn95:20.2.eng: Next, they place faith in them. When faith has arisen they approach the teacher. They pay homage, actively listen, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, examine their meaning, and accept them after deliberation. Then enthusiasm springs up; they apply zeal, weigh up, and strive. Striving, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.
mn95:20.2.comm: Here we see the meaning of the Buddhist “grounded faith” (ākāravatī saddhā, MN 47:16.1, MN 60:4.1) as opposed to “blind faith”. But faith is only the beginning of the long and demanding process described here.

mn95:20.3.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhāradvāja, saccānubodho hoti, ettāvatā saccamanubujjhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānubodhaṃ paññapema;
mn95:20.3.eng: That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the awakening to truth as defined in this way.

mn95:20.4.eng: But this is not yet the attainment of truth.”

mn95:21.1.pli: “Ettāvatā, bho gotama, saccānubodho hoti, ettāvatā saccamanubujjhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānubodhaṃ pekkhāma.
mn95:21.1.eng: “That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, worthy Gotama. I regard the awakening to truth as defined in this way.

mn95:21.2.pli: Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, saccānuppatti hoti, kittāvatā saccamanupāpuṇāti?
mn95:21.2.eng: But worthy Gotama, how do you define the attainment of truth?”

mn95:21.4.pli: “Tesaṃyeva, bhāradvāja, dhammānaṃ āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkammaṃ saccānuppatti hoti.
mn95:21.4.eng: “By the cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things there is the attainment of truth.
mn95:21.4.comm: Typically this distinction refers to the stream-enterer and the arahant.

mn95:21.5.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhāradvāja, saccānuppatti hoti, ettāvatā saccamanupāpuṇāti, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānuppattiṃ paññapemā”ti.
mn95:21.5.eng: That’s how the attainment of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the attainment of truth as defined in this way.”

mn95:22.1.pli: “Ettāvatā, bho gotama, saccānuppatti hoti, ettāvatā saccamanupāpuṇāti, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānuppattiṃ pekkhāma.
mn95:22.1.eng: “That’s how the attainment of truth is defined, worthy Gotama. I regard the attainment of truth as defined in this way.

mn95:22.2.pli: Saccānuppattiyā pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
mn95:22.2.eng: But what quality is helpful for arriving at the truth?”

mn95:22.3.pli: Saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:22.4.eng: “Striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.

mn95:22.5.eng: If you don’t strive, you won’t arrive at the truth.

mn95:22.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho padahati tasmā saccamanupāpuṇāti.
mn95:22.6.eng: You arrive at the truth because you strive.

mn95:22.7.eng: That’s why striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.”

mn95:23.1.pli: “Padhānassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
mn95:23.1.eng: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”

mn95:23.2.pli: Padhānassa bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:23.3.eng: “Weighing up the teachings is helpful for striving …
mn95:23.3.comm: Tulanā is literally “weighing”, here in the applied sense of “evaluating”.

mn95:23.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho tuleti tasmā padahati.

mn95:24.1.pli: “Tulanāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:24.2.pli: Tulanāya bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:24.3.eng: Zeal is helpful for weighing up the teachings …
mn95:24.3.comm: Here, “zeal” (ussāha) is making an effort to understand the teachings, while “striving” (padhāna) is making an effort in meditation.

mn95:24.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho ussahati tasmā tuleti.

mn95:25.1.pli: “Ussāhassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:25.2.pli: Ussāhassa bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:25.4.pli: No cetaṃ chando jāyetha, nayidaṃ ussaheyya.

mn95:25.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho chando jāyati tasmā ussahati.

mn95:26.1.pli: “Chandassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:26.2.pli: Chandassa bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:26.3.eng: Acceptance of the teachings after deliberation is helpful for enthusiasm …

mn95:26.4.pli: No cete dhammā nijjhānaṃ khameyyuṃ, nayidaṃ chando jāyetha.

mn95:26.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho dhammā nijjhānaṃ khamanti tasmā chando jāyati.

mn95:27.1.pli: “Dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:27.2.pli: Dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:27.3.eng: Examining the meaning of the teachings is helpful for accepting them after deliberation …

mn95:27.4.pli: No cetaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkheyya, nayidaṃ dhammā nijjhānaṃ khameyyuṃ.

mn95:27.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho atthaṃ upaparikkhati tasmā dhammā nijjhānaṃ khamanti.

mn95:28.1.pli: “Atthūpaparikkhāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:28.2.pli: Atthūpaparikkhāya bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:28.3.eng: Remembering the teachings is helpful for examining their meaning …

mn95:28.4.pli: No cetaṃ dhammaṃ dhāreyya, nayidaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkheyya.

mn95:28.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho dhammaṃ dhāreti tasmā atthaṃ upaparikkhati.

mn95:29.1.pli: “Dhammadhāraṇāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:29.2.pli: Dhammadhāraṇāya bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:29.3.eng: Hearing the teachings is helpful for remembering the teachings …

mn95:29.4.pli: No cetaṃ dhammaṃ suṇeyya, nayidaṃ dhammaṃ dhāreyya.

mn95:29.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho dhammaṃ suṇāti tasmā dhammaṃ dhāreti.

mn95:30.1.pli: “Dhammassavanassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:30.2.pli: Dhammassavanassa bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:30.3.eng: Active listening is helpful for hearing the teachings …

mn95:30.4.pli: No cetaṃ sotaṃ odaheyya, nayidaṃ dhammaṃ suṇeyya.

mn95:30.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho sotaṃ odahati tasmā dhammaṃ suṇāti.

mn95:31.1.pli: “Sotāvadhānassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:31.2.pli: Sotāvadhānassa bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:31.3.eng: Paying homage is helpful for active listening …

mn95:31.4.pli: No cetaṃ payirupāseyya, nayidaṃ sotaṃ odaheyya.

mn95:31.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho payirupāsati tasmā sotaṃ odahati.

mn95:32.1.pli: “Payirupāsanāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:32.2.pli: Payirupāsanāya bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:32.3.eng: Approaching is helpful for paying homage …

mn95:32.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho upasaṅkamati tasmā payirupāsati.

mn95:33.1.pli: “Upasaṅkamanassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?

mn95:33.2.pli: Upasaṅkamanassa bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmā”ti.

mn95:33.3.eng: Faith is helpful for approaching a teacher.

mn95:33.4.pli: No cetaṃ saddhā jāyetha, nayidaṃ upasaṅkameyya.
mn95:33.4.eng: If you don’t give rise to faith, you won’t approach a teacher.

mn95:33.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho saddhā jāyati tasmā upasaṅkamati.
mn95:33.5.eng: You approach a teacher because you have faith.

mn95:33.6.eng: That’s why faith is helpful for approaching a teacher.”

mn95:34.1.pli: “Saccānurakkhaṇaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ apucchimha, saccānurakkhaṇaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo byākāsi;
mn95:34.1.eng: “I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about the preservation of truth, and he has answered me.

mn95:34.2.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
mn95:34.2.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn95:34.3.pli: Saccānubodhaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ apucchimha, saccānubodhaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo byākāsi;
mn95:34.3.eng: I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about awakening to the truth, and he has answered me.

mn95:34.4.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
mn95:34.4.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn95:34.5.pli: Saccānuppattiṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ apucchimha, saccānuppattiṃ bhavaṃ gotamo byākāsi;
mn95:34.5.eng: I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about the attainment of truth, and he has answered me.

mn95:34.6.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
mn95:34.6.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn95:34.7.pli: Saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ apucchimha, saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṃ dhammaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo byākāsi;
mn95:34.7.eng: I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about the things that are helpful for the attainment of truth, and he has answered me.

mn95:34.8.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
mn95:34.8.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn95:34.9.pli: Yaṃyadeva ca mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ apucchimha taṃtadeva bhavaṃ gotamo byākāsi;
mn95:34.9.eng: Whatever I have asked the worthy Gotama about he has answered me.

mn95:34.10.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
mn95:34.10.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn95:34.11.pli: Mayañhi, bho gotama, pubbe evaṃ jānāma:
mn95:34.11.eng: Worthy Gotama, I used to think this:

mn95:34.12.pli: ‘ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā bandhupādāpaccā, ke ca dhammassa aññātāro’ti?
mn95:34.12.eng: ‘Who are these shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman next to those who understand the teaching?’

mn95:34.13.pli: Ajanesi vata me bhavaṃ gotamo samaṇesu samaṇapemaṃ, samaṇesu samaṇapasādaṃ, samaṇesu samaṇagāravaṃ.
mn95:34.13.eng: The Buddha has inspired me to have love, confidence, and respect for ascetics!

mn95:35.2.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn95:35.2.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
mn95:35.2.comm: That Kāpaṭika should sincerely go forth does not conflict with him being a spy; it is a conversion story. In authoritarian countries today, spies are regularly placed in monasteries for the same reason. There are stories of how, after being placed for many years and seeing not a hotbed of sedition but a place for wisdom and goodness, such spies feel shame and genuinely convert to Buddhism.
